(JOURNAL)                 MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 2007                        1
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­
tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, Justice
Breyer, and Justice Alito.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “I have the honor to announce, on behalf of the Court, that the Octo­
ber 2006 Term of the Supreme Court of the United States is now
closed, and the October 2007 Term is now convened.
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certiﬁed,
and ﬁled with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                Certiorari—Summary Dispositions

   No. 06–1264. Peter D. Keisler, Acting Attorney General, Petitioner
v. Hong Yin Gao. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for further consideration in
light of Gonzales v. Thomas, 547 U. S. 183 (2006).
   No. 06–11085. Jimmy Edward May, Petitioner v. California. On peti­
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, Fifth
Appellate District. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the Court of Appeal of California, Fifth Appel­
late District, for further consideration in light of Cunningham v. Cali­
fornia, 549 U. S. ––– (2007).
   No. 06–11312. Isaac Scott Castaneda, Petitioner v. California. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, Fifth
Appellate District. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the Court of Appeal of California, Fifth Appel­
late District, for further consideration in light of Cunningham v. Cali­
fornia, 549 U. S. ––– (2007).
  No. 06–11361. L. C. Cohen, Petitioner v. Corrections Corporation of
America. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to pro­
ceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of
JNL07$1001—10-19-07 16:32:12     JOURNAPGT          MILES




2                        MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 2007

Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in light of Jones
v. Bock, 549 U. S. ––– (2007).
   No. 06–11735. Jose Remedios Munoz, Petitioner v. California. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California,
Third Appellate District. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg­
ment vacated, and case remanded to the Court of Appeal of California,
Third Appellate District, for further consideration in light of Cunning­
ham v. California, 549 U. S. ––– (2007).

JNL07$1001—10-19-07 16:32:12      JOURNAPGT          MILES




4                         MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 2007

period July 1, 2006 through June 30, 2007, to be paid equally by the
parties.
   No. 138, Original (06A1150). State of South Carolina, Plaintiff v.
State of North Carolina. Motion for leave to ﬁle a bill of complaint
granted. Defendant allowed thirty days within which to ﬁle an answer.
Application for preliminary injunction presented to The Chief Justice
and referred to the Court denied.
   No. 06–179. Charles R. Riegel, et ux., Petitioners v. Medtronic, Inc.
Motion of Donna Riegel, the administrator of the Estate of Charles R.
Riegel, to be substituted in place of Charles R. Riegel, deceased,
granted. The exercise of this Court’s power to grant an untimely mo­
tion to substitute a party is not unprecedented. State Farm Mutual
Auto. Ins. Co. v. Campbell, 537 U. S. 1042 (2002); see also Schact v.
United States, 398 U. S. 58, 63–64 (1970) (“The procedural rules
adopted by the Court for the orderly transaction of its business are
not jurisdictional and can be relaxed by the Court in the exercise of
its discretion . . .”); Stern & Gressman, Supreme Court Practice 350
(8th ed. 2002). The Chief Justice and Justice Scalia would deny the mo­
tion, because it was ﬁled more than six months after the petitioner’s
death. See Supreme Court Rule 35.1 (“If the substitution of a repre­
sentative of the deceased is not made within six months after the death
of the party, the case shall abate” (emphasis added)). The fact that Rule
35.1 is not jurisdictional is not a reason to ignore it, particularly since
here, unlike in Campbell, supra, the motion was opposed by the
respondent.
   No. 06–887. City of Revere, Massachusetts, et al., Petitioners v.
T&D Video, Inc., dba Moonlite Reader. Motion of respondent for attor­
ney’s fees and costs referred to the Appeals Court of Massachusetts
for adjudication.
   No. 06–1039. Estate of Roger Roxas, et al., Petitioners v. Mariano
J. Pimentel, et al.; and
   No. 06–1204. Republic of the Philippines, et al., Petitioners v. Mari­
ano J. Pimentel, et al. Motion of respondent Mariano J. Pimentel to set
a deadline for submission of an amicus brief by the Solicitor General
denied.
   No. 06–1196. Khaled A. F. Al Odah, Next Friend of Fawzi Khalid
Abdullah Fahad Al Odah, et al., Petitioners v. United States, et al.
Motion of International Law Scholars for leave to ﬁle a brief as amici
curiae granted.
   No. 06–1398. AT&T Pension Beneﬁt Plan, as Successor to the Ameri­
tech Management Pension Plan, Petitioner v. Linda Call, Individually
JNL07$1001—10-19-07 16:32:12     JOURNAPGT          MILES

6                        MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 2007

submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33.1 of the Rules of this

  No. 07–5142. Cecil O. Harvey, Petitioner v. Department of Homeland
Security. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
denied. Petitioner allowed until October 22, 2007, within which to pay
the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in
compliance with Rule 33.1 of the Rules of this Court.
   No. 07–5184. Thomas Clark, Petitioner v. Paragon Systems, Inc. Mo­
tion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied. Peti­
tioner allowed until October 22, 2007, within which to pay the docket­
ing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compliance
with Rule 33.1 of the Rules of this Court.
  No. 07–5938. Evelina R. Cavett, Petitioner v. Robert M. Gates, Sec­
retary of Defense, et al. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis denied. Petitioner allowed until October 22, 2007,
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­
tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, Justice

and ﬁled with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
  No. 06–1535. Stuart Hudson, Warden, Petitioner v. Frank G.
Spisak, Jr. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pau­
peris granted. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in light
of Carey v. Musladin, 549 U. S. ––– (2006), and Schriro v. Landrigan,
550 U. S. ––– (2007). Justice Stevens, Justice Ginsburg, and Justice
Breyer would deny the petition for writ of certiorari.

                     Orders in Pending Cases
  No. 07M16. Michael Mirayes, Petitioner v. New Jersey. Motion to
direct the Clerk to ﬁle a petition for writ of certiorari out of time
denied.
  No. 07M17. Cindy J. Stiggers, Petitioner v. Washington Mutual
Bank. Motion to direct the Clerk to ﬁle a petition for writ of certiorari
out of time denied.
  No. 06–1265. Klein & Co. Futures, Inc., Petitioner v. Board of Trade
of the City of New York, et al. Motion of the Solicitor General for
leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided
argument granted.
  No. 06–1322. Federal Express Corporation, Petitioner v. Paul Holo­
wecki, et al. Motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in
oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument granted.

                         Certiorari Denied
  No. 06–1361. Marcel Sfarcioc, Petitioner v. Peter D. Keisler, Acting

Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit denied.

                         TUESDAY, OCTOBER 9, 2007                    207
ess, the Clerk is directed not to accept any further petitions in noncrim­
inal matters from petitioner unless the docketing fee required by Rule
38(a) is paid and petition submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See
Martin v. District of Columbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992)
(per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases cited
therein.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­
tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certiﬁed,
and ﬁled with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

(JOURNAL)                TUESDAY, OCTOBER 16, 2007                     241
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­
tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, Justice
Breyer, and Justice Alito.

                       Order in Pending Case
   No. 07A311. Larry Norris, Director, Arkansas Department of Cor­
rections, Applicant v. Jack Harold Jones, Jr. Application to vacate the
stay of execution of sentence of death entered by the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit on October 11, 2007, presented
to Justice Alito and by him referred to the Court denied. Opinion by
Justice Scalia, dissenting from denial. I vote to grant the State’s appli­
cation to vacate the stay because in my view the decision of the Eighth
Circuit was based on the mistaken premise that our grant of certiorari
in Baze v. Rees, S. Ct. ––– (2007), calls for the stay of every execution
in which an individual raises an Eighth Amendment challenge to the
lethal injection protocol. Grant of certiorari in a single case does not
alter the application of normal rules of procedure, including those re­
lated to timeliness. In this case, Jones’s challenge to the lethal injection
protocol, which was brought nine years after his conviction and sen­
tence became ﬁnal, was dilatory.
JNL07$1017—10-31-07 21:50:47    JOURNAPGT           MILES




(JOURNAL)             WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 17, 2007                  243
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­
tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, Justice
Breyer, and Justice Alito.

                      Order in Pending Case
  No. 07A304. Christopher Scott Emmett, Applicant v. Gene M. John­
son, Director, Virginia Department of Corrections. Application for stay
presented to The Chief Justice and by him referred to the Court
granted. The execution of sentence of death is stayed pending ﬁnal
disposition of the appeal by the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit or further order of this Court.
JNL07$1029—11-06-07 11:30:10    JOURNAPGT          MILES




(JOURNAL)               MONDAY, OCTOBER 29, 2007                   245
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­
tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, Justice
Breyer, and Justice Alito.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certiﬁed,
and ﬁled with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                Certiorari—Summary Dispositions

   No. 07–5130. Jose Arquimides Ibarra, Petitioner v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eighth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg­
ment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Ap­
peals for the Eighth Circuit for further consideration in light of Rita
v. United States, 551 U. S. ––– (2007).
   No. 07–5473. John L. Heavner, Petitioner v. United States. On peti­
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit for further consideration in light of Rita v. United
States, 551 U. S. ––– (2007).
   No. 07–6522. Montgomery Blair Sibley, Petitioner v. Stephen Breyer,
Associate Justice, Supreme Court of the United States, et al. On peti­
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the District of Columbia Circuit. Because the Court lacks a quorum, 28
U. S. C. § 1, and since a majority of the qualiﬁed Justices are of the
opinion that the case cannot be heard and determined at the next Term
of the Court, the judgment is afﬁrmed under 28 U. S. C. § 2109, which
provides that under these circumstances the Court shall enter its order
afﬁrming the judgment of the court from which the case was brought
for review with the same effect as upon afﬁrmance by an equally di­
vided Court. Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice
Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer took no
part in the consideration or decision of this petition.

                       Order in Pending Case
  No. 07–7348 (07A367). Earl Wesley Berry, Petitioner v. Christopher
B. Epps, Commissioner, Mississippi Department of Corrections, et al.
Application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to
Justice Scalia and by him referred to the Court granted pending the
disposition of the petition for writ of certiorari. Should the petition for
writ of certiorari be denied, this stay shall terminate automatically. In
the event the petition for writ of certiorari is granted, the stay shall
terminate upon the sending down of the judgment of this Court. Justice
Scalia and Justice Alito would deny the application for stay of
execution.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­
tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, Justice
Breyer, and Justice Alito.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certiﬁed,
and ﬁled with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                         Opinion Per Curiam

  No. 06–1680. Richard F. Allen, Commissioner, Alabama Department
of Corrections, Petitioner v. Daniel Siebert. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Cir­
cuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment reversed, and
case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh
Circuit for further proceedings consistent with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens,
with whom Justice Ginsburg joins.

                         Certiorari Granted

   No. 07–110. Avron J. Arave, Warden, Petitioner v. Maxwell Hoffman.
Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit granted. In addition to the questions presented
by the petition, the parties are directed to brief and argue the following
question: “What, if any, remedy should be provided for ineffective as­
sistance of counsel during plea bargain negotiations if the defendant
was later convicted and sentenced pursuant to a fair trial?”

                         Mandamus Denied
   No. 07–6846. In Re Gabriel G. Atamian, Petitioner. Motion of peti­
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and petition for
writ of mandamus dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has repeat­
edly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to accept
JNL07$1105—11-14-07 10:03:54      JOURNAPGT         MILES




292                      MONDAY, NOVEMBER 5, 2007

any further petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner unless the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition submitted in
compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court
of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents.
See id., at 4, and cases cited therein. Justice Alito took no part in the
consideration or decision of this petition.

  No. 07–5916. In Re Gerald DeMarsh, Petitioner. Petitions for rehear­
ing denied.

for leave to ﬁle a petition for rehearing denied.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­

                       Order in Pending Case
  No. 07A383. Mark Dean Schwab, Applicant v. Florida. Application
for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Thomas
and by him referred to the Court granted pending the timely ﬁling and
disposition of a petition for writ of certiorari. Should the petition for
writ of certiorari be denied, this stay shall terminate automatically. In
the event the petition for writ of certiorari is granted, the stay shall
terminate upon the issuance of the mandate of this Court.
JNL07$1116—11-19-07 14:32:50     JOURNAPGT          MILES




(JOURNAL)               FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 2007                   329
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­
tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, Justice
Breyer, and Justice Alito.
   No. 06–989. Hall Street Associates, L.L.C., Petitioner v. Mattel, Inc.
Parties are directed to ﬁle supplemental briefs addressing the follow­
ing questions: (1) Does authority exist outside the Federal Arbitration
Act (FAA) under which a party to litigation begun without reliance on
the FAA may enforce a provision for judicial review of an arbitration
award? (2) If such authority does exist, did the parties, in agreeing to
arbitrate, rely in whole or part on that authority? (3) Has petitioner in
the course of this litigation waived any reliance on authority outside
the FAA for enforcing the judicial review provision of the parties’ arbi­
tration agreement? Briefs, not to exceed 6,000 words, are to be ﬁled
simultaneously with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or
before 2 p.m., Tuesday, November 27, 2007. Reply briefs, not to exceed
3,000 words, may be ﬁled with the Clerk and served upon opposing
counsel on or before 2 p.m., Monday, December 3, 2007.
JNL07$1120—09-16-08 16:03:04      JOURNAPGT          MILES

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, Justice

  No. 07–77. Bob Riley, Governor of Alabama, Appellant v. Yvonne

Heller. Petition for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit granted limited to the
following question: Whether the following provisions-D. C. Code §§ 7­
2502.02(a)(4), 22-4504(a), and 7-2507.02-violate the Second Amendment
rights of individuals who are not afﬁliated with any state-regulated
militia, but who wish to keep handguns and other ﬁrearms for private
use in their homes?

JNL07$1203—12-21-07 12:30:57      JOURNAPGT          MILES




(JOURNAL)                MONDAY, DECEMBER 3, 2007                     369
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­
tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, Justice
Breyer, and Justice Alito.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certiﬁed,
and ﬁled with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”
  The Chief Justice said:
  “The Court now recognizes the Solicitor General of the United
States.”
  Solicitor General Clement said:
  “Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court. I have the honor to
present to the Court the eighty-ﬁrst Attorney General of the United
States, the Honorable Michael B. Mukasey of New York.”
   The Chief Justice said:
   “General Mukasey, on behalf of the Court I welcome you as the chief
law ofﬁcer of the United States government and as an ofﬁcer of this
Court. We welcome you to the performance of your very important
duties that will rest upon you by virtue of your ofﬁce. Your commission
as Attorney General of the United States will be placed in the records
of the Court, and we wish you well in your new ofﬁce.”
  Attorney General Mukasey said:
  “Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice.”

                      Orders in Pending Cases

to direct the Clerk to ﬁle a petition for writ of certiorari out of time
denied.
  No. 07M24. Don Hamrick, Petitioner v. George W. Bush, President
of the United States, et al. Motion for leave to proceed as a seaman
denied.
  No. 06–937. Quanta Computer, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. LG Elec­
tronics, Inc. Motion of petitioners for leave to ﬁle Volume II of the joint
appendix under seal granted.
   No. 06–1346. Ahmed Ali, Petitioner v. Deborah Achim, et al. Motion
of petitioner to dispense with printing the joint appendix granted.

   No. 07–21. William Crawford, et al., Petitioners v. Marion County

   No. 07–25. Indiana Democratic Party, et al., Petitioners v. Todd Rok­

                        Certiorari Granted

  No. 06–1204. Republic of the Philippines, et al., Petitioners v. Mari­
ano J. Pimentel, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted. In addition to
the question presented by the petition, the parties are directed to brief
and argue on the following question: Whether the Republic of the Phil­
ippines (Republic) and its Presidential Commission on Good Govern­
ment (PCGG), having been dismissed from the interpleader action
based on their successful assertion of sovereign immunity, had the
right to appeal the district court’s determination that they were not
indispensable parties under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 19(b); and
whether the Republic and its PCGG have the right to seek this Court’s
review of the court of appeals’s opinion afﬁrming the district court.
  No. 07–308. United States, Petitioner v. Clintwood Elkhorn Mining
Company, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit granted.
  No. 07–440. Walter A. Rothgery, Petitioner v. Gillespie County,
Texas. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted.

   No. 07–6768. Marzuq Al-Hakim, Petitioner v. Publix Supermarkets.
Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied,
and petition for writ of certiorari to the District Court of Appeal of
Florida, Second District, dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has
repeatedly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to
accept any further petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner
unless the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition
submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Co­
lumbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Ste­
vens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.
   No. 07–6778. Kevin Rondeau, Petitioner v. Supreme Court of New
Hampshire. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pau­
peris denied, and petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
New Hampshire dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has repeatedly
abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to accept any
further petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner unless the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition submitted in
compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court
of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents.
See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.

                       Order in Pending Case
   No. 07–395 (07A451). Thomas D. Arthur, Petitioner v. Richard F.
Allen, Commissioner, Alabama Department of Corrections, et al. Appli­
cation for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice
Thomas and by him referred to the Court granted pending the disposi­
tion of the petition for writ of certiorari. Should the petition for writ
of certiorari be denied, this stay shall terminate automatically. In the
event the petition for writ of certiorari is granted, the stay shall termi­
nate upon the sending down of the judgment of this Court.

  No. 06–1666. Mohammad Munaf, et al., Petitioners v. Pete Geren,
Secretary of the Army, et al.; and
  No. 07–394. Pete Geren, Secretary of the Army, et al., Petitioners v.
Sandra K. Omar and Ahmed S. Omar, as Next Friends of Shawqi
Ahmad Omar. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit granted. The
cases are consolidated and a total of one hour is allotted for oral
argument.

Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit granted.
  No. 07–208. Indiana, Petitioner v. Ahmad Edwards. Motion of re­
spondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Indiana granted limited to
the following question: “May States adopt a higher standard for mea­
suring competency to represent oneself at trial than for measuring
competency to stand trial?"
  No. 07–312. Florida Department of Revenue, Petitioner v. Piccadilly
Cafeterias, Inc. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit granted.

writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit granted.
  No. 07–480. Pam Huber, Petitioner v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit granted limited to Question 1 presented by the petition.
Justice Breyer took no part in the consideration or decision of this
petition.

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
  No. 07–6032. Jose Eduardo Lopez, Petitioner v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eleventh Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Elev­
enth Circuit for further consideration in light of Bowles v. Russell, 551
U. S. ––– (2007).

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­
tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, Justice
Breyer, and Justice Alito.

                     Orders in Pending Cases

   No. 06–1082. Virginia, Petitioner v. David Lee Moore. Motion of
American Bar Association for leave to participate in oral argument as
amicus curiae and for divided argument denied.
   No. 07–21. William Crawford, et al., Petitioners v. Marion County
Election Board, et al.; and
   No. 07–25. Indiana Democratic Party, et al., Petitioners v. Todd Rok­
ita, Indiana Secretary of State, et al. Motion of the Solicitor General
for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for
divided argument granted.
   No. 07–5439. Ralph Baze and Thomas C. Bowling, Petitioners v. John
D. Rees, Commissioner, Kentucky Department of Corrections, et al.
Motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral argument
as amicus curiae and for divided argument granted.

                        Certiorari Granted

  No. 06–7517. Richard Irizarry, Petitioner v. United States. Motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eleventh Circuit granted. Brief of petitioner to be ﬁled on or before
Thursday, February 14, 2008. Brief of respondent to be ﬁled on or be­
fore Wednesday, March 12, 2008. Reply brief, if any, to be ﬁled in ac­
cordance with Rule 25.3 of the Rules of this Court.
  No. 07–210. John Bridge, et al., Petitioners v. Phoenix Bond & In­
demnity Co., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit granted limited to the follow­
ing question: “Whether reliance is a required element of a RICO claim
predicated on mail fraud and, if it is, whether that reliance must be by
the plaintiff.” Brief of petitioners to be ﬁled on or before Thursday,
February 14, 2008. Brief of respondents to be ﬁled on or before
Wednesday, March 12, 2008. Reply brief, if any, to be ﬁled in accordance
with Rule 25.3 of the Rules of this Court.

   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certiﬁed,
and ﬁled with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                          Opinions Per Curiam
  No. 07–212. Randall Wright, Sheriff, Shawano County, Wisconsin,
Petitioner v. Joseph L. Van Patten. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Petition
for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment reversed, and case remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for fur­
ther proceedings consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per
curiam. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in the judgment.
  No. 07–110. Avron J. Arave, Warden, Petitioner v. Maxwell Hoffman.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Motion of respondent to vacate the decision
below and dismiss as moot granted. Judgment vacated, and case re­
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
with directions that it instruct the United States District Court for
the District of Idaho to dismiss the relevant claim with prejudice. Opin­
ion per curiam.

for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pau­
peris and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit for further consideration in light of Kimbrough v.
United States, 552 U. S. ––– (2007).

pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,

  No. 07–7894. Gbeke Michael Awala, Petitioner v. Five United States
Supreme Court Justices, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Because the
Court lacks a quorum, 28 U. S. C. § 1, and since a majority of the quali­
ﬁed Justices are of the opinion that the case cannot be heard and deter­
mined at the next Term of the Court, the judgment is afﬁrmed under
28 U. S. C. § 2109, which provides that under these circumstances the
Court shall enter its order afﬁrming the judgment of the court from
JNL07$0107—09-16-08 16:22:15     JOURNAPGT          MILES




                         MONDAY, JANUARY 7, 2008                     431
which the case was brought for review with the same effect as upon
afﬁrmance by an equally divided Court. The Chief Justice, Justice Ken­
nedy, Justice Souter, Justice Ginsburg, and Justice Alito took no part
in the consideration or decision of this petition.

peals for the Eighth Circuit for further consideration in light of Kim­
brough v. United States, 552 U. S. ––– (2007).

                       Order in Pending Case
  No. 138, Original. State of South Carolina, Plaintiff v. State of
North Carolina. Kristin Linsley Myles, Esq., of San Francisco, Califor­
nia, is appointed Special Master in this case with authority to ﬁx the
time and conditions for the ﬁling of additional pleadings, to direct sub­
sequent proceedings, to summon witnesses, to issue subpoenas, and to
take such evidence as may be introduced and such as she may deem it
necessary to call for. The Special Master is directed to submit Reports
as she may deem appropriate. The compensation of the Special Master,
the allowances to her, the compensation paid to her legal, technical,
stenographic and clerical assistants, the cost of printing her Reports,
and all other proper expenses, including travel expenses, shall be
charged against and be borne by the parties in such proportion as the
Court may hereafter direct. The motions of Catawba River Water Sup­
ply Project and Duke Energy Carolinas, LLC, for leave to intervene
are referred to the Special Master.

(JOURNAL)                FRIDAY, JANUARY 18, 2008                   537
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­
tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, Justice
Breyer, and Justice Alito.

                        Certiorari Granted
   No. 06–923. Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, et al., Petitioners
v. Wanda Glenn. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit granted limited to Question 1
presented by the petition and the following question: “If an administra­
tor that both determines and pays claims under an ERISA plan is
deemed to be operating under a conﬂict of interest, how should that
conﬂict be taken into account on judicial review of a discretionary bene­
ﬁt determination?” Brief of petitioners to be ﬁled on or before Monday,
February 25, 2008. Brief of respondent to be ﬁled on or before Monday,
March 24, 2008. Reply brief, if any, to be ﬁled in accordance with Rule
25.3 of the Rules of this Court.
   No. 06–1249. Wyeth, Petitioner v. Diana Levine. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Vermont granted. Brief of peti­
tioner to be ﬁled on or before Monday, February 25, 2008. Brief of
respondent to be ﬁled on or before Monday, March 24, 2008. Reply
brief, if any, to be ﬁled in accordance with Rule 25.3 of the Rules of
this Court.
   No. 06–1505. Clifford B. Meacham, et al., Petitioners v. Knolls
Atomic Power Laboratory, aka KAPL, Inc., et al. Motion of AARP and
National Lawyers Association for leave to ﬁle a brief as amici curiae
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit granted limited to Question 1 presented
by the petition. Brief of petitioners is to be ﬁled on or before Monday,
February 25, 2008. Brief of respondents to be ﬁled on or before Monday,
March 24, 2008. Reply brief, if any, to be ﬁled in accordance with Rule
25.3 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Breyer took no part in the

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Jus­
tice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, and Justice Alito.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certiﬁed,
and ﬁled with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                Certiorari—Summary Dispositions

  No. 06–560. Avis Budget Group, Inc., fka Cendant Corporation,
et al., Petitioners v. California State Teachers’ Retirement System,
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of
Stoneridge Investment Partners, LLC v. Scientiﬁc-Atlanta, Inc., 552
U. S. ––– (2008).
   No. 07–678. Michael K. C. Tom, Petitioner v. United States. On peti­
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the First Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment va­
cated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the First Circuit for further consideration in light of Gall v. United
States, 552 U. S. ––– (2007).
   No. 07–6294. Felipe de Jesus Contreras-Hurtado, aka Felipe
Contreras-Hurtado, Petitioner v. United States. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.

tion for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case re­
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Gall v. United States, 552 U. S.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, Justice

                       Order in Pending Case
   No. 07A630. James Callahan, Applicant v. Richard F. Allen, Commis­
sioner, Alabama Department of Corrections, et al. Application for stay
of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Thomas and by
him referred to the Court granted pending the timely ﬁling and dispo­
sition of a petition for writ of certiorari. Should the petition for writ
of certiorari be denied, this stay shall terminate automatically. In the
event the petition for writ of certiorari is granted, the stay shall termi­
nate upon the sending down of the judgment of this Court.

(JOURNAL)              TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 2008                   557
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­
tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, Justice
Breyer, and Justice Alito.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certiﬁed,
and ﬁled with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                  Certiorari—Summary Dispositions

  No. 07–470. Tom Robinson, et al., Petitioners v. Candace Lehman.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment
vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of Scott v. Harris,
550 U. S. ––– (2007). Justice Stevens and Justice Ginsburg would deny
the petition for writ of certiorari.
  No. 07–7962. Michael J. D’Amico, Petitioner v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the First Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the First
Circuit for further consideration in light of Gall v. United States, 552
U. S. ––– (2007).
   No. 07–8388. Esteban Rivera, Petitioner v. United States. On peti­
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit for further consideration in light of Gall v. United
States, 552 U. S. ––– (2007).
  No. 07–8399. Anthony Wayne Silver, Petitioner v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fourth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit for further consideration in light of Gall v. United
States, 552 U. S. ––– (2007).

compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court
of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents.

                       Attorney Discipline

  No. D–2449. In the Matter of Discipline of Berthold H. Hoeniger.
Berthold H. Hoeniger, of Bridgewater, Connecticut, is suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and a rule will issue, returnable within
40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
  No. D–2450. In the Matter of Discipline of Samuel Aaron Abady.
Samuel Aaron Abady, of Bronxville, New York, is suspended from the
practice of law in this Court and a rule will issue, returnable within
40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–2451. In the Matter of Discipline of Ben J. Zander. Ben J.
Zander, of Loretto, Pennsylvania, is suspended from the practice of law
in this Court and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days, requiring
him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice
of law in this Court.

(JOURNAL)             WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 20, 2008                   629
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­
tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, Justice
Breyer, and Justice Alito.
                               Opinions

   No. 06–457. G. Steven Rowe, Attorney General of Maine, Petitioner
v. New Hampshire Motor Transport Association, et al. On writ of cer­
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit.
Judgment afﬁrmed. Opinion by Justice Breyer. Concurring opinion by
Justice Ginsburg. Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring in part.
   No. 06–1463. Arnold M. Preston, Petitioner v. Alex E. Ferrer. On
writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appel­
late District. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the Court of
Appeal of California, Second Appellate District, for further proceed­
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Ginsburg. Dissenting opinion by Justice Thomas.
   No. 06–179. Donna S. Riegel, Individually and as Administrator of
the Estate of Charles R. Riegel, Petitioner v. Medtronic, Inc. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit. Judgment afﬁrmed. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Opinion by Jus­
tice Stevens, concurring in part and concurring in the judgment. Dis­
senting opinion by Justice Ginsburg.
   No. 06–856. James LaRue, Petitioner v. DeWolff, Boberg & Associ­
ates, Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further pro­
ceedings consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Stevens. Opinion by The Chief Justice, with whom Justice Kennedy
joins, concurring in part and concurring in the judgment. Opinion by
Justice Thomas, with whom Justice Scalia joins, concurring in the
judgment.
  No. 06–8273. Stephen Danforth, Petitioner v. Minnesota. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Minnesota. Judgment reversed, and
case remanded to the Supreme Court of Minnesota for further proceed­
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Stevens. Dissenting opinion by The Chief Justice, with whom Justice
Kennedy joins.

   No. 07–1054. Robert M. Gates, Secretary of Defense, et al., Petition­
ers v. Haji Bismullah, et al. Respondents are directed to ﬁle a response

(JOURNAL)              MONDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 2008                   633
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­
tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, Justice
Breyer, and Justice Alito.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certiﬁed,
and ﬁled with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                  Certiorari—Summary Dispositions

   No. 06–10446. Paul Ezra Rhoades, Petitioner v. Idaho. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Idaho. Motion of peti­
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of
certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the Su­
preme Court of Idaho for further consideration in light of Danforth v.
Minnesota, 552 U. S. ––– (2008).
   No. 06–10841. Randy Lynn McKinney, Petitioner v. Idaho. On peti­
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Idaho. Motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ
of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the
Supreme Court of Idaho for further consideration in light of Danforth
v. Minnesota, 552 U. S. ––– (2008).
   No. 06–11010. Gerald Ross Pizzuto, Jr., Petitioner v. Idaho. On peti­
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Idaho. Motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ
of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the
Supreme Court of Idaho for further consideration in light of Danforth
v. Minnesota, 552 U. S. ––– (2008).
   No. 06–12010. David Leslie Card, Petitioner v. Idaho. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Idaho. Motion of peti­
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of
certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the Su­
preme Court of Idaho for further consideration in light of Danforth v.
Minnesota, 552 U. S. ––– (2008).
  No. 07–5634. James H. Hairston, Petitioner v. Idaho. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Idaho. Motion of petitioner
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certio­
rari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the Supreme
JNL07$0225—03-10-08 12:07:09     JOURNAPGT          MILES




634                     MONDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 2008

Court of Idaho for further consideration in light of Danforth v. Minne­
sota, 552 U. S. ––– (2008).
   No. 07–6393. Joseph R. Lave, Jr., Petitioner v. Texas. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. Motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ

the Eighth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit for further consideration in light of Kimbrough v.
United States, 552 U. S. ––– (2007).

ﬁled. Exceptions to the Report, with supporting briefs, may be ﬁled

  No. 07–526. Donald L. Carcieri, Governor of Rhode Island, et al.,
Petitioners v. Dirk Kempthorne, Secretary of the Interior, et al. Motion
of Citizens Equal Rights Foundation, et al., for leave to ﬁle a brief as
amici curiae out of time denied. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit granted limited
to Questions 1 and 2 presented by the petition.
  No. 07–542. Arizona, Petitioner v. Rodney Joseph Gant. Motion of
National Association of Police Organizations, Inc., for leave to ﬁle a
brief as amicus curiae granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
Supreme Court of Arizona granted limited to the following question:
Does the Fourth Amendment require law enforcement ofﬁcers to dem­
onstrate a threat to their safety or a need to preserve evidence related
to the crime of arrest in order to justify a warrantless vehicular search
incident to arrest conducted after the vehicle’s recent occupants have
been arrested and secured?
  No. 07–544. Chris Chrones, Warden, Petitioner v. Michael Robert
Pulido. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted.

   No. 07–8273. Randall Lamont Rolle, Petitioner v. Nicole Raysor,

   No. 07–8461. Charles Lavel Stringer, Petitioner v. Michael J. Astrue,
Commissioner of Social Security. Motion of petitioner for leave to pro­
ceed in forma pauperis denied, and petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit dismissed. See
Rule 39.8. As petitioner has repeatedly abused this Court’s process, the
Clerk is directed not to accept any further petitions in noncriminal
matters from petitioner unless the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a)
is paid and petition submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin
v. District of Columbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per cu­
riam). Justice Stevens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.
   No. 07–8960. Gbeke Michael Awala, Petitioner v. John G. Roberts,
Jr., Chief Justice of the United States, et al.; and Gbeke M. Awala,
Petitioner v. City of Chicago, Illinois, et al. Motion of petitioner for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit
dismissed. See Rule 39.8. The Chief Justice and Justice Alito took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion and this petition.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­

                      Order in Pending Case
  No. 07–953. Citizens United, Appellant v. Federal Election Commis­
sion. Parties are directed to submit brieﬁng addressing the question
whether this Court has jurisdiction to hear the appeal in light of the
language in 28 U. S. C. § 1253 permitting a direct appeal “in any civil
action, suit or proceeding required by any Act of Congress to be heard
and determined by a district court of three judges.” Briefs, not to ex­
ceed 3,000 words, are to be ﬁled simultaneously with the Clerk and
served upon opposing counsel on or before 2 p.m., Monday, March 10,
2008. Reply briefs, not to exceed 2,000 words, may be ﬁled with the
Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 2 p.m., Thursday,
March 13, 2008.
JNL07$0303—03-10-08 16:36:19     JOURNAPGT          MILES




(JOURNAL)                 MONDAY, MARCH 3, 2008                     659
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Jus­
tice Souter, Justice Ginsburg, and Justice Alito.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certiﬁed,
and ﬁled with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                Certiorari—Summary Dispositions
  No. 07–836. Carlos Espinola, Petitioner v. United States. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
First Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the First
Circuit for further consideration in light of Gall v. United States, 552
U. S. ––– (2007).
  No. 07–8023. Steven Wayne Pruett, Petitioner v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit for further consideration in light of Watson v. United
States, 552 U. S. ––– (2007).

                     Orders in Pending Cases
  No. 07A612 (07-9171). Montgomery Blair Sibley, Applicant v. Flor­
ida Supreme Court, et al. Application for stay addressed to Justice
Ginsburg and referred to the Court denied.
  No. 07M48. Jeffrey Plaza, Petitioner v. Michael J. Astrue, Commis­
sioner of Social Security. Motion to direct the Clerk to ﬁle a petition
for writ of certiorari out of time denied.
  No. 07M49. Mark Anthony Flores, Petitioner v. Robert C. Hernan­
dez, Warden. Motion to direct the Clerk to ﬁle a petition for writ of
certiorari out of time denied.
  No. 07M50. James L. Paris, Petitioner v. United States. Motion to
direct the Clerk to ﬁle a petition for writ of certiorari out of time
denied.
  No. 07M51. Marilyn Merriman, Petitioner v. John E. Potter, Post­
master General. Motion to direct the Clerk to ﬁle a petition for writ of
certiorari out of time denied.

JNL07$0303—03-10-08 16:36:19     JOURNAPGT          MILES




                          MONDAY, MARCH 3, 2008                     671
peatedly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to accept
any further petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner unless the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition submitted in
compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court
of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents.
See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.

                         Mandamus Denied
   No. 07–845. In Re Aaron Raiser, Petitioner; and
   No. 07–8560. In Re Robert D. Lefort, Petitioner. Petitions for writs
of mandamus denied.

(JOURNAL)                 MONDAY, MARCH 17, 2008                    681
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­
tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, Justice
Breyer, and Justice Alito.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “We are very pleased to have visiting with us this morning, Vice
President Brigitte Bierlein and her colleagues from the Constitutional
court of Austria. On behalf of my colleagues, welcome.”
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certiﬁed,
and ﬁled with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                Certiorari—Summary Dispositions
   No. 07–7723. Jacqueline Lorraine Holtz, Petitioner v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Tenth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg­
ment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Ap­
peals for the Tenth Circuit for further consideration in light of Gall v.
United States, 552 U. S. ––– (2007).
   No. 07–7948. Guillermo Rodriguez-Flores, Petitioner v. United
States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg­
ment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Ap­
peals for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of Gall v.
United States, 552 U. S. ––– (2007).
   No. 07–9033. LeAnne Soperla, Petitioner v. United States. On peti­
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit for further consideration in light of Gall v. United
States, 552 U. S. ––– (2007).
   No. 07–9207. Tito Melvin, Petitioner v. United States. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pau­
peris and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,

                          Oral Arguments
  No. 06–1204. Republic of the Philippines, et al., Petitioners v. Jerry
S. Pimentel, Temporary Administrator of the Estate of Mariano J.
Pimentel, deceased, et al. Argued by Mr. Charles A. Rothfeld for the
petitioners, by Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler for the United States as amicus
curiae, by special leave of the Court, supporting the petitioners, and
by Mr. Robert A. Swift for the respondents.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Mr. Kneedler, our records reﬂect that you have now presented oral
argument before this Court in 100 cases, beginning with your ﬁrst
argument in October 1979. You are the ﬁrst to reach this rare milestone
this Century.
  “On behalf of the Court, I extend to you our appreciation for the
many years of advocacy and service to the Court during your tenure
in the Ofﬁce of the Solicitor General. We look forward to hearing from
you many more times in the future. Thank you.”
  Mr. Kneedler said:
  “Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice. It has been a great honor.”
  No. 07–440. Walter A. Rothgery, Petitioner v. Gillespie County,
Texas. Argued by Ms. Danielle Spinelli for the petitioner and by
Mr. Gregory S. Coleman for the respondent.


  Adjourned until Tuesday, March 18, 2008, at 10 o’clock.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­
tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, Justice
Breyer, and Justice Alito.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certiﬁed,
and ﬁled with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                     Appeal—Summary Disposition
  No. 07–953. Citizens United, Appellant v. Federal Election Commis­
sion. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Columbia. Appeal dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Justice Breyer
would afﬁrm the judgment.

                Certiorari—Summary Dispositions
   No. 07–9256. Carla Erica Gonzales Sanchez, Petitioner v. United
States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg­
ment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Ap­
peals for the Tenth Circuit for further consideration in light of Gall v.
United States, 552 U. S. ––– (2007).
   No. 07–9289. Jonathan Carnell Williams, Petitioner v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg­
ment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Ap­
peals for the Fourth Circuit for further consideration in light of Gall
v. United States, 552 U. S. ––– (2007).

   No. 07–8950. Eddie Lee Thompson, Petitioner v. Barry Davis, War­
den. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis de­
nied, and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner
has repeatedly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not
to accept any further petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner
unless the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition
submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of
Columbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice
Stevens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.
   No. 07–9195. Vincent P. Murray, Petitioner v. David H. Souter, Asso­

petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit dismissed. See Rule 39.8. Justice Souter took no part in
the consideration or decision of this motion and this petition.

                        Attorney Discipline

  No. D–2452. In the Matter of Discipline of Charles P. Mirarchi, III.
Charles P. Mirarchi, III, of West Chester, Pennsylvania, is suspended
from the practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable
within 40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

                               Opinions

   No. 06–989. Hall Street Associates, L.L.C., Petitioner v. Mattel, Inc.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings
consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Souter.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens, with whom Justice Kennedy
joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Breyer.
   No. 06–984. Jose Ernesto Medellin, Petitioner v. Texas. On writ of
certiorari to Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. Judgment afﬁrmed.
Opinion by The Chief Justice. Opinion by Justice Stevens, concurring in
the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Breyer, with whom Justice
Souter and Justice Ginsburg join.

  Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.

  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certiﬁed,
and ﬁled with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 07–9376. Ricky Eugene Everhart, Petitioner v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg­
ment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Ap­
peals for the Fourth Circuit for further consideration in light of Gall
v. United States, 552 U. S. ––– (2007), and Kimbrough v. United States,
552 U. S. ––– (2007).

   No. 07–9633. Jimmy Lee Fields, Petitioner v. United States Court
of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis denied, and petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit dis­
missed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has repeatedly abused this Court’s
process, the Clerk is directed not to accept any further petitions in
noncriminal matters from petitioner unless the docketing fee required
by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition submitted in compliance with Rule
33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1
(1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases
cited therein.

                                 Opinion

   No. 134, Original. State of New Jersey, Plaintiff v. State of Dela­
ware. On Exceptions to the Report of the Special Master and on Bill
of Complaint. Delaware’s authority to deny permission for the Crown
Landing terminal is conﬁrmed, New Jersey’s exceptions are overruled,
and the decree proposed by the Special Master is entered with modiﬁ­
cations consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Ginsburg. Opinion by Justice Stevens, concurring in part and dissent­
ing in part. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia, with whom Justice
Alito joins. Justice Breyer took no part in the consideration or decision
of this case.

(JOURNAL)                 FRIDAY, APRIL 11, 2008                    767
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­
tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, Justice
Breyer, and Justice Alito.

                     Orders in Pending Cases
   No. 06–923. Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, et al., Petitioners
v. Wanda Glenn. Motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate
in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument granted.
   No. 06–1505. Clifford B. Meacham, et al., Petitioners v. Knolls
Atomic Power Laboratory, aka KAPL, Inc., et al. Motion of the Solici­
tor General for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae
and for divided argument granted. Justice Breyer took no part in the
consideration or decision of this motion.
   No. 07–474. Anup Engquist, Petitioner v. Oregon Department of
Agriculture, et al. Motion of the Solicitor General for leave to partici­
pate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument
granted.

(JOURNAL)                 MONDAY, APRIL 14, 2008                   769
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­
tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, Justice
Breyer, and Justice Alito.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “We are very pleased to have visiting with us this morning Chief
Justice Thimjo Kondi and his colleagues from the Supreme Court of
Albania. On behalf of my colleagues, welcome.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certiﬁed,
and ﬁled with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                  Certiorari—Summary Dispositions
   No. 07–7937. Terri Pruitt, Petitioner v. United States. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Tenth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pau­
peris and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth
Circuit for further consideration in light of Gall v. United States, 552
U. S. ––– (2007).
   No. 07–8292. Leonard Warren, Petitioner v. United States. On peti­
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Sixth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit for further consideration in light of Gall v. United States, 552
U. S. ––– (2007).
                      Orders in Pending Cases
   No. 07A584. Patrick J. Muhammad, Applicant v. United States Court
of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, et al. Application for stay addressed
to Justice Stevens and referred to the Court denied.
   No. 07M61. Paul H. Noe, Petitioner v. Michael J. Astrue, Commis­
sioner of Social Security, et al. Motion to direct the Clerk to ﬁle a
petition for writ of certiorari out of time denied.
   No. 07M62. Anthony Campbell, Petitioner v. Isolation Technologies,
Inc. Motion to direct the Clerk to ﬁle a petition for writ of certiorari
out of time under Rule 14.5 denied.

770                       MONDAY, APRIL 14, 2008

  No. 06–1195. Lakhdar Boumediene, et al., Petitioners v. George W.

tary, Pennsylvania Department of Corrections, et al. Motion of peti­

pauperis denied.
   No. 07–9358. Christy Mathis, Petitioner v. Wachovia Bank. Motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied. Petitioner
allowed until May 5, 2008, within which to pay the docketing fee re­
quired by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule
33.1 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Thomas took no part in the
consideration or decision of this motion.

                        Certiorari Granted

   No. 07–588. Entergy Corporation, Petitioner v. Riverkeeper, Inc.,
et al.;
   No. 07–589. PSEG Fossil LLC, et al., Petitioners v. Riverkeeper,
Inc., et al.; and
   No. 07–597. Utility Water Act Group, Petitioner v. Riverkeeper, Inc.,
et al. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit granted limited to the following ques­
tion: Whether Section 316(b) of the Clean Water Act, 33 U. S. C.
1326(b), authorizes the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to
compare costs with beneﬁts in determining the “best technology avail­
able for minimizing adverse environmental impact” at cooling water
intake structures. The cases are consolidated and a total of one hour is
allotted for oral argument.

ers Insurance Company of Florida, et al. Motion of petitioner for leave

   No. 07–9262. Warren R. Skillern, Petitioner v. Roger Garrison, Sher­
iff, Cherokee County, Georgia. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis denied, and petition for writ of certiorari to the
Supreme Court of Georgia dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has
repeatedly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to
accept any further petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner
unless the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition
submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Co­
lumbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Ste­
vens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.
  No. 07–9268. Xiangyuan Zhu, Petitioner v. Federal Housing Finance
Board, et al. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pau­
peris denied, and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit dismissed. See Rule 39.8.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­
tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, Justice
Breyer, and Justice Alito.
                               Opinions
  No. 06–1413. MeadWestvaco Corporation, Successor in Interest to
the Mead Corporation, Petitioner v. Illinois Department of Revenue,
et al. On writ of certiorari to Appellate Court of Illinois, First District.
Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the Appellate Court of Illi­
nois, First District, for further proceedings not inconsistent with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Alito. Concurring opinion by
Justice Thomas.
  No. 07–308. United States, Petitioner v. Clintwood Elkhorn Mining
Company, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Federal Circuit. Judgment reversed. Opinion by The
Chief Justice.

                               Opinions

  No. 06–11543. Larry Begay, Petitioner v. United States. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit.
Judgment reversed in relevant part, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit for further proceedings
consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Breyer.
Opinion by Justice Scalia, concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opin­
ion by Justice Alito, with whom Justice Souter and Justice Thomas join.
  No. 06–11429. Keith Lavon Burgess, Petitioner v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit. Judgment afﬁrmed. Opinion by Justice Ginsburg.
  No. 07–5439. Ralph Baze and Thomas C. Bowling, Petitioners v. John
D. Rees, Commissioner, Kentucky Department of Corrections, et al.
On writ of certiorari to Supreme Court of Kentucky. Judgment af­
ﬁrmed. The Chief Justice announced the judgment of the Court and
delivered an opinion, in which Justice Kennedy and Justice Alito join.
Concurring opinion by Justice Alito. Opinion by Justice Stevens, con­
curring in the judgment. Opinion by Justice Scalia, with whom Justice
Thomas joins, concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Justice Thomas,
with whom Justice Scalia joins, concurring in the judgment. Opinion
by Justice Breyer, concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Ginsburg, with whom Justice Souter joins.

                       Order in Pending Case
   No. 07A841. Bob Riley, Governor of Alabama, Applicant v. Fred L.
Plump. Application for stay of judgment of the United States District
Court for the Middle District of Alabama, case No. 2:07–cv–1014, en­
tered January 22, 2008, and amended January 25, 2008, presented to
Justice Thomas and by him referred to the Court granted pending the
timely docketing of the appeal in this Court. Should the jurisdictional
statement be timely ﬁled, this order shall remain in effect pending this
Court’s action on the appeal. If the appeal is dismissed, or judgment
afﬁrmed, this order shall terminate automatically. In the event jurisdic­
tion is noted or postponed, this order will remain in effect pending the
sending down of the judgment of this Court.

(JOURNAL)               WEDNESDAY, APRIL 23, 2008                  837
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­
tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, Justice
Breyer, and Justice Alito.

                               Opinion

  No. 06–1082. Virginia, Petitioner v. David Lee Moore. On writ of
certiorari to Supreme Court of Virginia. Judgment reversed, and case
remanded to the Supreme Court of Virginia for further proceedings
not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Scalia. Opinion by Justice Ginsburg, concurring in the judgment.

                           Oral Arguments
   No. 06–923. Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, et al., Petitioners
v. Wanda Glenn. Argued by Ms. Amy K. Posner for the petitioners, by
Mr. E. Joshua Rosenkranz for the respondent, and by Ms. Nicole A.
Saharsky for the United States as amicus curiae, by special leave of
the Court, supporting the respondent.
   No. 06–1505. Clifford B. Meacham, et al., Petitioners v. Knolls
Atomic Power Laboratory, aka KAPL, Inc., et al. Argued by Mr. Kevin
K. Russell for the petitioners, by Mr. Daryl Joseffer for the United
States as amicus curiae, by special leave of the Court, supporting the
petitioners, and by Mr. Seth P. Waxman for the respondents. Justice
Breyer recused.


  Adjourned until Monday, April 28, 2008, at 10 o’clock.


                                Orders
  Ordered:
  1. That the Supplemental Rules for Admiralty or Maritime Claims
and Asset Forfeiture Actions be, and they hereby are, amended by
including therein the amendment to Rule C.
JNL07$0423—04-30-08 16:41:27      JOURNAPGT          MILES




                         WEDNESDAY, APRIL 23, 2008                    839
   2. That the foregoing amendment to the Supplemental Rules for Ad­
miralty or Maritime Claims and Asset Forfeiture Actions shall take
effect on December 1, 2008, and shall govern in all proceedings thereaf­
ter commenced and, insofar as just and practicable, all proceedings
then pending.
   3. That The Chief Justice be, and hereby is, authorized to transmit
to the Congress the foregoing amendment to the Supplemental Rules
for Admiralty or Maritime Claims and Asset Forfeiture Actions in ac­
cordance with the provisions of Section 2072 of Title 28, United
States Code.
   Ordered:
   1. That the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure be, and they
hereby are, amended by including therein amendments to Criminal
Rules 1, 12.1, 17, 18, 32, 41, 45, 60, and new Rule 61.
   2. That the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of Criminal
Procedure shall take effect on December 1, 2008, and shall govern in
all proceedings thereafter commenced and, insofar as just and practica­
ble, all proceedings then pending.
   3. That The Chief Justice be, and hereby is, authorized to transmit
to the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of
Criminal Procedure in accordance with the provisions of Section 2072,
of Title 28, Untied States Code.
  Ordered:
  1. That the Federal Rules of Bankruptcy Procedure be, and they
hereby are, amended by including therein amendments to Bankruptcy
Rules 1005, 1006, 1007, 1009, 1010, 1011, 1015, 1017, 1019, 1020, 2002,
2003, 2007.1, 2015, 3002, 3003, 3016, 3017.1, 3019, 4002, 4003, 4004, 4006,
4007, 4008, 5001, 5003, 6004, 7012, 7022, 7023.1, 8001, 8003, 9006, 9009,
and 9024, and new Rules 1021, 2007.2, 2015.1, 2015.2, 2015.3, 5008, and
6011.
  2. That the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of Bank­
ruptcy Procedure shall take effect on December 1, 2008, and shall gov­
ern in all proceedings in bankruptcy cases thereafter commenced and,
insofar as just and practicable, all proceedings then pending.
  3. That The Chief Justice be, and hereby is, authorized to transmit
to the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of
Bankruptcy Procedure in accordance with the provisions of Section
2075 of Title 28, United States Code.

(JOURNAL)                 MONDAY, APRIL 28, 2008                    841
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certiﬁed,
and ﬁled with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                  Certiorari—Summary Dispositions

   No. 07–745. United States, Petitioner v. ABC. Motion of the Solicitor
General for leave to ﬁle Appendix B to the petition for writ of certio­
rari under seal granted. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Petition for writ of
certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for further con­
sideration in light of Ali v. Federal Bureau of Prisons, 552 U. S. –––
(2008).
   No. 07–9799. Guadalupe Alberto Garcia-Lara, Jr., Petitioner v.
United States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Tenth Circuit for further consideration in light of Gall
v. United States, 552 U. S. ––– (2007).
  No. 07–9824. Deborah Ahmad Bey, Petitioner v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Seventh Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sev­
enth Circuit for further consideration in light of Gall v. United States,
552 U. S. ––– (2007).
