JNL07$0512—05-22-08 09:43:38     JOURNAPGT          MILES




(JOURNAL)                  MONDAY, MAY 12, 2008                      865
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­
tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, Justice
Breyer, and Justice Alito.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certiﬁed,
and ﬁled with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                   Certiorari—Summary Dispositions
   No. 07–919. American Isuzu Motors, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Lun­
gisile Ntsebeza, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Because the Court
lacks a quorum, 28 U. S. C. § 1, and since a majority of the qualiﬁed
Justices are of the opinion that the case cannot be heard and deter­
mined at the next Term of the Court, the judgment is afﬁrmed under
28 U. S. C. § 2109, which provides that under these circumstances the
Court shall enter its order afﬁrming the judgment of the court from
which the case was brought for review with the same effect as upon
afﬁrmance by an equally divided Court. The Chief Justice, Justice Ken­
nedy, Justice Breyer, and Justice Alito took no part in the consideration
or decision of this petition.
   No. 07–8178. Omar Bennett, Petitioner v. United States. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pau­
peris and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit for further consideration in light of the position asserted by the
Solicitor General in his brief for the United States ﬁled April 4, 2008.
   No. 07–8709. Jorge Alberto Alvarado-Molina, Petitioner v. United
States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg­
ment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Ap­
peals for the Tenth Circuit for further consideration in light of Gall v.
United States, 552 U. S. ––– (2007).
   No. 07–8833. Rosendo Rodriguez-Izaguirre, Petitioner v. United
States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
JNL07$0512—05-22-08 09:43:38     JOURNAPGT          MILES




866                        MONDAY, MAY 12, 2008

in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg­
ment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Ap­
peals for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of Gall v.
United States, 552 U. S. ––– (2007).
  No. 07–8856. Jose Marmolejo-Sanchez, Petitioner v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit for further consideration in light of Gall v. United States, 552
U. S. ––– (2007).
  No. 07–8859. Anthony Robert Kittredge, Petitioner v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Tenth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg­
ment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Ap­
peals for the Tenth Circuit for further consideration in light of Gall v.
United States, 552 U. S. ––– (2007).
  No. 07–8907. Artemio Andrade-Real, Petitioner v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals

(JOURNAL)                   MONDAY, MAY 19, 2008                       895
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Jus­
tice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Breyer, and Justice Alito.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certiﬁed,
and ﬁled with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                 Certiorari—Summary Dispositions

  No. 07–6054. Justin Metuchen Gamba, Petitioner v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg­
ment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Ap­
peals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of Gonza­
lez v. United States, 553 U. S. ––– (2008). Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia,
and Justice Alito would deny the petition for writ of certiorari.
  No. 07–10259. Marquis Townsend, Petitioner v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit for further consideration in light of Gall v. United States, 552
U. S. ––– (2007), and Kimbrough v. United States, 552 U. S. ––– (2007).

                      Orders in Pending Cases

  No. 07A304. Christopher Scott Emmett, Applicant v. Gene M. John­
son, Director, Virginia Department of Corrections, et al. Motion to va­
cate the stay of execution of sentence of death issued by the Court on
October 17, 2007, granted. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens, with
whom Justice Souter and Justice Ginsburg join.
  No. 07M68. Kinder Canal Company, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Mike
Johanns, Secretary of Agriculture. Motion to direct the Clerk to ﬁle a
petition for writ of certiorari out of time denied.
  No. 07–8950. Eddie Lee Thompson, Petitioner v. Barry Davis, War­
den. Motion of petitioner for reconsideration of order denying leave to
proceed in forma pauperis denied.
JNL07$0519—05-29-08 12:22:32    JOURNAPGT          MILES




896                       MONDAY, MAY 19, 2008

   No. 07–9179. Charles Lavel Stringer, Petitioner v. American Bank­
ers Insurance Company of Florida, et al. Motion of petitioner for recon­
sideration of order denying leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied.
   No. 07–9195. Vincent P. Murray, Petitioner v. David H. Souter, Asso­
ciate Justice, Supreme Court of the United States, et al. Motion of
petitioner for reconsideration of order denying leave to proceed
in forma pauperis denied. Justice Souter took no part in the consider­
ation or decision of this motion.
   No. 07–9808. Robert A. Heghmann, et ux., Petitioners v. Town of
Rye, New Hampshire, et al. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis denied. Petitioner allowed until June 9, 2008, within
which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a
petition in compliance with Rule 33.1 of the Rules of this Court.

peris denied, and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States

As petitioner has repeatedly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is
directed not to accept any further petitions in noncriminal matters
from petitioner unless the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid
and petition submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v.
District of Columbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam).
Justice Stevens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.

                               Opinions
   No. 06–1646. United States, Petitioner v. Gino Gonzaga Rodriquez.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings
consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Alito.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Souter, with whom Justice Stevens and
Justice Ginsburg join.
   No. 06–666. Department of Revenue of Kentucky, et al., Petitioners
v. George W. Davis, et ux. On writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals
of Kentucky. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals of Kentucky for further proceedings not inconsistent with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Souter, except as to Part
III–B. Concurring opinion by Justice Stevens. Opinion by The Chief
Justice, concurring in part. Opinion by Justice Scalia, concurring in
part. Opinion by Justice Thomas, concurring in the judgment. Dissent­
ing opinion by Justice Kennedy, with whom Justice Alito joins. Dissent­
ing opinion by Justice Alito.
   No. 06–694. United States, Petitioner v. Michael Williams. On writ of
certiorari to United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit.
Judgment reversed. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Concurring opinion by
Justice Stevens, with whom Justice Breyer joins. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Souter, with whom Justice Ginsburg joins.
   No. 07–455. United States, Petitioner v. Ahmed Ressam. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

and ﬁled with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                   Certiorari—Summary Disposition
  No. 07–9390. Oscar Arreguin-Aguilar, Petitioner v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eleventh Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg­
ment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Ap­
peals for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in light of the
position asserted by the Solicitor General in his brief for the United
States ﬁled April 21, 2008.

  No. 07–10194. Leo Stoller, Petitioner v. Attorney Registration and
Disciplinary Commission. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis denied, and petition for writ of certiorari to the

repeatedly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to
accept any further petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner
unless the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition
submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Co­
lumbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Ste­
vens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.

   No. 07–10062. In Re Carl B. Adams, Petitioner. Petitions for writs
of mandamus denied.
   No. 07–9976. In Re Robert D. Gibson, Petitioner. Motion of peti­
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and petition for
writ of mandamus dismissed. See Rule 39.8.
  No. 07–10049. In Re Leander George Davis, Petitioner. Petition for
writ of mandamus denied. Justice Alito took no part in the consider­
ation or decision of this petition.
  No. 07–10076. In Re Royce Eugene Mitchell, Jr., Petitioner. Petition
for writ of mandamus and/or prohibition denied.

                               Opinions
   No. 06–1321. Myrna Gomez-Perez, Petitioner v. John E. Potter, Post­
master General. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the First Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit for further
proceedings consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Jus­
tice Alito. Dissenting opinion by The Chief Justice, with whom Justice
Scalia and Justice Thomas join as to all but Part I. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Thomas, with whom Justice Scalia joins.
   No. 06–1431. CBOCS West, Inc., Petitioner v. Hedrick G. Humph­
ries. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Seventh Circuit. Judgment afﬁrmed. Opinion by Justice Breyer.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Thomas, with whom Justice Scalia joins.
   No. 07–77. Bob Riley, Governor of Alabama, Appellant v. Yvonne
Kennedy, et al. On appeal from the United States District Court for the
Middle District of Alabama. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to
the United States District Court for the Middle District of Alabama
for further proceedings consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opin­
ion by Justice Ginsburg. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens, with
whom Justice Souter joins.

and ﬁled with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                               Opinions
   No. 06–1717. Richlin Security Service Company, Petitioner v. Mi­
chael Chertoff, Secretary of Homeland Security. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. Judgment
reversed, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Federal Circuit for further proceedings consistent with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Alito.
   No. 06–1456. Humberto Fidel Regalado Cuellar, Petitioner v. United
States. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed. Opinion by Justice Thomas.
Concurring opinion by Justice Alito, with whom The Chief Justice and
Justice Kennedy join.
   No. 06–1005. United States, Petitioner v. Efrain Santos and Bene­
dicto Diaz. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment afﬁrmed. Justice Scalia announced
the judgment of the Court and delivered an opinion, in which Justice
Souter and Justice Ginsburg join, and in which Justice Thomas joins as
to all but Part IV. Opinion by Justice Stevens, concurring in the judg­
ment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Breyer. Dissenting opinion by Jus­
tice Alito, with whom The Chief Justice, Justice Kennedy and Justice
Breyer join.

  The Chief Justice said:
  “General Clement, could I have you approach the lectern please?
  “The Court at this time wishes to note for the record that you have
been serving as the Solicitor General since July 10, 2004. The Court
recognizes the signiﬁcant responsibilities that were placed upon you to
represent the government of the United States before this Court and
to perform other important functions on behalf of the Executive
Branch.
  “On behalf of my colleagues, I thank you, General Clement, for a
job well done. You have our sincere appreciation and best wishes for
the future.”


  Adjourned until Monday, June 9, 2008, at 10 o’clock.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­
tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, Justice
Breyer, and Justice Alito.

   No. 07–11232 (07A954). In Re Curtis Osborne, Petitioner. Applica­

habeas corpus denied.

(JOURNAL)                 MONDAY, JUNE 9, 2008                     961
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­
tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Breyer, and Jus­
tice Alito.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certiﬁed,
and ﬁled with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                Certiorari—Summary Dispositions

  No. 06–1604. Samuel Ness, Petitioner v. United States. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment va­
cated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit for further consideration in light of Regalado Cuellar v.
United States, 553 U. S. ––– (2008).
  No. 06–11863. Leonardo Nunez-Virraizabal, Petitioner v. United
States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to pro­
ceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in light of
Regalado Cuellar v. United States, 553 U. S. ––– (2008).
  No. 07–400. Roberto Moreno-Gonzalez, Petitioner v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eleventh Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg­
ment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Ap­
peals for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in light of
Regalado Cuellar v. United States, 553 U. S. ––– (2008).
   No. 07–834. Radian Guaranty, Inc., Petitioner v. Whitney Whitﬁeld,
et al. Motion of Consumer Mortgage Coalition, et al. for leave to ﬁle
a brief as amici curiae granted. Motion of Consumer Data Industry
Association for leave to ﬁle a brief as amicus curiae granted. Motion
of Washington Legal Foundation, et al. for leave to ﬁle a brief as amici
curiae granted. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit with instructions to dismiss

the case as moot. See United States v. Munsingwear, Inc., 340 U. S.

   No. 07–6082. Sergio Balderas, Petitioner v. United States. On peti­

the Fifth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit for further consideration in light of Regalado Cuellar v. United

and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit for further consideration in light of Gall v. United
States, 552 U. S. ––– (2007).

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­
tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, Justice
Breyer, and Justice Alito.

                               Opinions

   No. 07–371. Brent Taylor, Petitioner v. Robert A. Sturgell, Acting
Administrator, Federal Aviation Administration, et al. On writ of cer­
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Colum­
bia Circuit. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit for further pro­
ceedings consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Ginsburg.
   No. 06–1195. Lakhdar Boumediene, et al., Petitioners v. George W.
Bush, President of the United States, et al.; and
   No. 06–1196. Khaled A. F. Al Odah, Next Friend of Fawzi Khalid-
Abdullah Fahad Al Odah, et al., Petitioners v. United States, et al. On
writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Dis­
trict of Columbia Circuit. Judgment reversed. The cases are remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia
Circuit with instructions that it remand the cases to the United States
District Court for the District of Columbia for further proceedings
consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Kennedy.
Concurring opinion by Justice Souter, with whom Justice Ginsburg and
Justice Breyer join. Dissenting opinion by The Chief Justice, with
whom Justice Scalia, Justice Thomas, and Justice Alito join. Dissenting
opinion announced by Justice Scalia, with whom The Chief Justice, Jus­
tice Thomas, and Justice Alito join.
   No. 06–1204. Republic of the Philippines, et al., Petitioners v. Jerry
S. Pimentel, Temporary Administrator of the Estate of Mariano J.
Pimentel, deceased, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
with instructions to order the United States District Court for the
District of Hawaii to dismiss the interpleader action. Opinion by Jus­
tice Kennedy. Opinion by Justice Stevens, concurring in part and dis­
senting in part. Opinion by Justice Souter, concurring in part and dis­
senting in part.
JNL07$0612—06-15-08 14:03:46     JOURNAPGT         MILES




986                      THURSDAY, JUNE 12, 2008

   No. 06–7517. Richard Irizarry, Petitioner v. United States. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh
Circuit. Judgment afﬁrmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Concurring
opinion by Justice Thomas. Dissenting opinion by Justice Breyer, with
whom Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, and Justice Ginsburg join.
   No. 06–1666. Mohammad Munaf, et al., Petitioners v. Pete Geren,
Secretary of the Army, et al.; and
   No. 07–394. Pete Geren, Secretary of the Army, et al., Petitioners v.
Sandra K. Omar and Ahmed S. Omar, as Next Friends of Shawqi
Ahmad Omar. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgments and the in­
junction entered against the United States are vacated, and the cases
are remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the District
of Columbia Circuit for further proceedings consistent with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by The Chief Justice. Concurring opinion by
Justice Souter, with whom Justice Ginsburg and Justice Breyer join.

(JOURNAL)                  MONDAY, JUNE 16, 2008                     987
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­
tice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, Justice Breyer, and Jus­
tice Alito.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certiﬁed,
and ﬁled with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                   Certiorari—Summary Dispositions

   No. 07–1283. Paul Brown, et al., Petitioners v. Cassens Transport
Co., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in light of
Bridge v. Phoenix Bond & Indemnity Co., 553 U. S. ––– (2008).
  No. 07–9713. Alfonso Lopez-Morales, Petitioner v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit for further consideration in light of Gall v. United States, 552
U. S. ––– (2007).
  No. 07–9769. Pedro Jaimes-Aguirre, Petitioner v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit for further consideration in light of Gall v. United States, 552
U. S. ––– (2007).
  No. 07–9855. Pedro Salazar-Garcia, Petitioner v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit for further consideration in light of Gall v. United States, 552
U. S. ––– (2007).

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

                             Opinions
   No. 06–923. Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, et al., Petitioners
v. Wanda Glenn. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment afﬁrmed. Opinion by Justice
Breyer. Opinion by The Chief Justice, concurring in part and concur­
ring in the judgment. Opinion by Justice Kennedy, concurring in part
and dissenting in part. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia, with whom
Justice Thomas joins.
   No. 06–1037. Kentucky Retirement Systems, et al., Petitioners v.
Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment
reversed. Opinion by Justice Breyer. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Kennedy, with whom Justice Scalia, Justice Ginsburg, and Justice
Alito join.
   No. 07–208. Indiana, Petitioner v. Ahmad Edwards. On writ of cer­
tiorari to Supreme Court of Indiana. Judgment vacated, and case re­
manded to the Supreme Court of Indiana for further proceedings not
inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Breyer.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia, with whom Justice Thomas joins.
   No. 06–1505. Clifford B. Meacham, et al., Petitioners v. Knolls
Atomic Power Laboratory, aka KAPL, Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judg­
ment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Ap­
peals for the Second Circuit for further proceedings consistent with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Souter. Opinion by Justice
Scalia, concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Justice Thomas, concur­
ring in part and dissenting in part. Justice Breyer took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
   No. 06–939. Chamber of Commerce of the United States of America,
et al., Petitioners v. Edmund G. Brown, Jr., Attorney General of Cali­
fornia, et al. On writ of certiorari to United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. The Court of Appeals’ judgment reversing the
summary judgment entered for the Chamber of Commerce is reversed,
and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
JNL07$0619—06-24-08 13:34:12     JOURNAPGT         MILES




1010                     THURSDAY, JUNE 19, 2008

the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings consistent with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Breyer, with whom Justice Ginsburg joins.

(JOURNAL)                  MONDAY, JUNE 23, 2008                     1013
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­
tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, Justice
Breyer, and Justice Alito.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certiﬁed,
and ﬁled with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                Certiorari—Summary Dispositions

   No. 06–1039. Estate of Roger Roxas, et al., Petitioners v. Jerry S.
Pimentel, Temporary Administrator of the Estate of Mariano J. Pimen­
tel, deceased, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The Court reversed the
judgment below in Republic of Philippines v. Pimentel, 553 U. S. –––
(2008). Therefore, the petition for writ of certiorari is granted, and case
is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Cir­
cuit for further proceedings.
  No. 07–153. Saifullah Paracha, Petitioner v. George W. Bush, Presi­
dent of the United States, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Cir­
cuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of
Columbia Circuit for further consideration in light of Boumediene v.
Bush, 553 U. S. ––– (2008).
   No. 07–416. Abu Abdul Rauf Zalita, Petitioner v. George W. Bush,
President of the United States, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia
Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and
case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the District
of Columbia Circuit for further consideration in light of Boumediene v.
Bush, 553 U. S. ––– (2008).
   No. 07–495. Lavonna Eddy and Kathy Lander, Petitioners v. Wafﬂe
House, Inc. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further consideration in
light of Taylor v. Sturgell, 553 U. S. ––– (2008).
JNL07$0623—07-08-08 16:23:08       JOURNAPGT           MILES




1014                        MONDAY, JUNE 23, 2008

   No. 07–818. Armando Nunez, Petitioner v. United States. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment va­
cated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Seventh Circuit for further consideration in light of the position
asserted by the Solicitor General in his brief for the United States ﬁled
May 12, 2008. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia, with whom The
Chief Justice and Justice Thomas join.
   No. 07–1054 (07A677). Robert M. Gates, Secretary of Defense,
et al., Petitioners v. Haji Bismullah, et al. On petition for writ of certio­
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia
Circuit. Application for stay presented to The Chief Justice and by him
referred to the Court denied. Motion of respondents for leave to pro­
ceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit for further consideration
in light of Boumediene v. Bush, 553 U. S. ––– (2008).
   No. 07–9267. Twan Stephenson, Petitioner v. United States. On peti­
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Seventh Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit for further consideration in light of the position as­
serted by the Solicitor General in his brief for the United States ﬁled
May 12, 2008. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia, with whom The
Chief Justice and Justice Thomas join.

the Seventh Circuit denied.

   No. 07–10445. Lamar Fletcher, Petitioner v. Board of Professional

   No. 07–10486. Robert Tedder, Petitioner v. Grantt Culliver, Warden.

                       Habeas Corpus Denied

   No. 07–11154. In Re Eric Adams, Petitioner. Motion of petitioner

habeas corpus dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has repeatedly
abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to accept any
further petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner unless the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition submitted in
compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court

of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents.

   No. 07–219. Exxon Shipping Company, et al., Petitioners v. Grant
Baker, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap­
peals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit to remit puni­

Justice Stevens, concurring in part and dissenting in part. Opinion

  No. 07–343. Patrick Kennedy, Petitioner v. Louisiana. On writ of
certiorari to Supreme Court of Louisiana. Judgment upholding capital
sentence reversed. Case remanded to the Supreme Court of Louisiana
for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.

whom The Chief Justice, Justice Scalia, and Justice Thomas join.
   No. 07–6053. Dwayne Giles, Petitioner v. California. On writ of cer­

remanded to the Supreme Court of California for further proceedings
not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Scalia except as to Part II–D–2. Concurring opinion by Justice Thomas.

whom Justice Ginsburg joins, concurring in part. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Breyer, with whom Justice Stevens and Justice Kennedy join.

part, concurring in the judgment in part, and dissenting in part.

and Justice Ginsburg join.

  “I am authorized to announce that the Court has acted on all cases

1038                    THURSDAY, JUNE 26, 2008

Conference will be reﬂected on the Order List that will be released at

until the ﬁrst Monday in October 2008, at which time the October 2007
Term of the Court will be adjourned and the October 2008 Term of the
Court will begin as provided by law.
  “My colleagues and I thank the members of the Court staff for their
superb work and dedication to duty. The outstanding work done by the
members of the Court staff contributes signiﬁcantly to the accomplish­
ment of the Court’s mission.
  “We also thank the members of the Supreme Court Bar for their
professionalism and cooperation.”

sentence of death;

tion of sentence of death presented to Justice Scalia, and by him re­
ferred to the Court denied. Petition for writ of habeas corpus denied.

(JOURNAL)               MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 8, 2008                    1081
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­
tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, Justice
Breyer, and Justice Alito.

                       Order in Pending Case
   No. 07–343. Patrick Kennedy, Petitioner v. Louisiana. Petitioner Pat­
rick Kennedy is invited to ﬁle a supplemental brief, not to exceed 4,500
words, addressing not only whether rehearing should be granted but
also the merits of the issue raised in the petition for rehearing. The
brief should be ﬁled with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel
by 2:00 p.m. Wednesday, September 17, 2008. The Acting Solicitor Gen­
eral is invited to ﬁle at the same time a brief, not to exceed 2,500 words,
expressing the views of the United States. Respondent Louisiana is
invited to ﬁle a supplemental brief, not to exceed 4,500 words, also
addressing the merits of the issue raised in the petition for rehearing.
The brief should be ﬁled with the Clerk and served upon opposing
counsel by 2:00 p.m. Wednesday, September 24, 2008.

(JOURNAL)               TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 23, 2008                  1085
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­
tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, Justice
Breyer, and Justice Alito.

                       Order in Pending Case
  No. 08–66 (08A241). Troy Anthony Davis, Petitioner v. Georgia.
Application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to
Justice Thomas and by him referred to the Court granted pending the
disposition of the petition for writ of certiorari. Should the petition for
writ of certiorari be denied, this stay shall terminate automatically. In
the event the petition for writ of certiorari is granted, the stay shall
terminate upon the issuance of the mandate of this Court.


                          Certiorari Denied
   No. 08–6392 (08A248). Richard Henyard, Petitioner v. Florida. Ap­
plication for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice
Thomas and by him referred to the Court denied. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida denied.

JNL07$10A1—10-07-08 16:28:49      JOURNAPGT          MILES




(JOURNAL)              WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 1, 2008                   1087
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus­
tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, Justice
Breyer, and Justice Alito.

                      Petition for Rehearing

   No. 07–343. Patrick Kennedy, Petitioner v. Louisiana. The opinion of
the Court is modiﬁed by the addition of a footnote at page 15, after the
word “considered” in the last paragraph of Part II–A. The dissenting
opinion is modiﬁed by the addition of the words “a federal district court
to impose” at page 13 between the words “a law permitting” and the
words “the death penalty” in the ﬁrst paragraph of Part I–E; and by
the addition of footnote 6 after the word “values” in said paragraph.
The petition for rehearing is denied. Statement by Justice Kennedy,
with whom Justice Stevens, Justice Souter, Justice Ginsburg, and Jus­
tice Breyer join, respecting the denial of the petition for rehearing.
Statement by Justice Scalia, with whom The Chief Justice joins, re­
specting denial of the petition for rehearing. Justice Thomas and Jus­
tice Alito would grant the petition for rehearing.

                       Order in Pending Case

  No. 07–689. Gary Bartlett, Executive Director of the North Carolina
State Board of Elections, et al., Petitioners v. Dwight Strickland, et al.
Motion of the Acting Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral
argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument granted.

                         Certiorari Granted

  No. 07–1309. Edmund Boyle, Petitioner v. United States. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit granted.
  No. 07–1356. Kansas, Petitioner v. Donnie Ray Ventris. Motion of
respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Kansas granted.
  No. 07–1372. Hawaii, et al., Petitioners v. Ofﬁce of Hawaiian Affairs,
et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Hawaii
granted.

   No. 07–1410. United States, Petitioner v. Navajo Nation. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal
Circuit granted.
   No. 07–1529. Jesse Jay Montejo, Petitioner v. Louisiana. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Louisiana granted.
   No. 07–1601. Burlington Northern and Santa Fe Railway Company,
et al., Petitioners v. United States, et al. and
   No. 07–1607. Shell Oil Company, Petitioner v. United States, et al.
Petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit granted. The cases are consolidated and a total
of one hour is allotted for oral argument.
   No. 07–9712. James Benjamin Puckett, Petitioner v. United States.
Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit granted limited to the following question: “Whether a
forfeited claim that the government breached a plea agreement is sub­
ject to the plain-error standard of Rule 52(b) of the Federal Rules of
Criminal Procedure.”
   No. 07–9995. Michael Rivera, Petitioner v. Illinois. Motion of peti­
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Illinois granted.
   No. 07–10441. Johnnie Corley, Petitioner v. United States. Motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit granted.

spondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Vermont granted.
